texts.author: @NewYorkGiantsBlood
texts.text: Here's an idea. Leave gig workers tf alone!

texts.author: @brenthunter5078
texts.text:
I get that being an employee has quite a few benefits, but here me out. This is extremely bad. Maybe you like working for an employer. That's fine, but if you are a gig worker, being emoployee means all of the things that attracted you to being one will be gone overnight.


My main point is that as an employee, you are owned just like a slave. Yes, you are payed, so technically, it doesn't qualify as slavery, but courts have upheld firings over social networking posts which had nothing to do with work or the specific business in question. They have upheld firings of people for doing something outside of work and off of the employer's property. If your boss wants to fire you for being a scorpio, visiting a bar on the weekend, or making a political post about legalizing marijuana, there is no law, in most states, banning them from doing it.

They can promise you a forty hour workweek and suddenly require you to work sixty, threatening to fire you if you don't. Of course, not all employers do that, but they can. 

As an independent contractor, you work for multiple bosses. One might be strict while others aren't so much. If you prefer to dress casually or not work weekends, the only thing that happens is that you lose a few of these bosses. You decide whether or not to follow certain rules to bring in more work. 

 yes, your agent, someone like Uber or Lyft who provides you with work might have rules, so it can be similar, but currently, they are pretty hands off, and that's because of your classification as an independent contractor. It changes completely when you become an employee.


It won't be the same job but with a requirement that you get minimum wage and employee benefits like medical insurance. That would come at the price of being a gig worker. You would be a full time employee. You would work the hours your employer says to work. Yes, there are jobs where you do this anyway, but ride share drivers and delivery drivers currently enjoy flexibility which will disappear if they are classified as employees.

Even our cab companies require that you work a shift. Yes, you lease the vehicle and operate basicly as your own boss, but the timing of the whole thing is up to the company who owns and maintains the vehicle. 

Where I live, after traveling expenses, drivers are making $19 to $21 per hour on the top end. Yes, this is before taxes, but that means $13 to $15 after taxes, Fica, etc if you factor that in. If you are an employee, you get whatever the boss decides to give you regardless of how many passengers you pick up. In a slower market, this will be great for the few drivers on the road, because they will get payed way more for working less and get employee benefits, but if you carry a lot of passengers, there is no guarantee that you will be payed more for that. If there is a lot of competition for rides, that means there are too many drivers on the road, so Uber or Lyft won't hire as many or will lay people off. There might even be a required quota of fares you must carry to keep your job.  

You will also have to be hired as an employee. You won't be able to just download the app, fill out everything, photograph your license, plate, car, face, and insurance information, then wait for the back ground check, you'll have to apply, wait for an interview, then wait to be contacted. 

As mentioned above, your pay will not be equal to your work. You might be payed based on an average of the amount of rides any particular driver sells in a given shift, but that's all you get no matter how many more than that average you pick up.If your boss decides to reward you, maybe you'll get a raise or bonus, just like if you kiss a lot of ass at Walmart or Amazon. In Evansville Indiana, you might be offered $13 an hour before taxes are taken out, and you'll take it or leave it. Delivery drivers get tipped, so you'll get less. You might get $7.25 and be told to be greatful, because tipped workers do not have to be given minimum wage, and your boss has been gracious enough to give that to you anyway.


Of course, I think a lot of you are counting on that $15 minimum wage to save you. I don't see that happening, but if it does, it won't save you. It'll just mean that you have to work for the largest companies around. Nothing smaller than a full sized conglomerate will survive without quickly rushing to mechanize everything and downsizing workers as well as outsourcing to countries with much lower minimum wages. Did you know, 9/11 has been outsourced in many places. You, for the time being, are transfered to an operator here in the United States before being connected back to your local emergency services, so the time you speak to a call center employee is short, and they do speak your language enough to understand you even if you are panicking, or maybe even injured yourself and seconds from death, but what if that changes? 

You might have an emergency, dial 9/11, and hear a thickly accented voice say, "Thank you for calling nine one one, how may I help you today," and you'll have to relay not only your address but the city, state, and the zipcode and possibly repeat it a few times. If you are on the side of the road somewhere, the operator will still need something to input in to the computer before they can transfer you to the right personel in your area, so you might just be screwed.
California has given special treatment to Uber and Lyft, but will that spill over to the whole country if this is federalized? What about Grubhub, Doordash, Roadie, etc? There's no way of knowing what this administration will do, and many of you voted for Joe Biden, because at least he isn't Donald Trump. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't remember the bad ol orange man saying anything negative about the gig economy.

CA Prop 22, which would classify gig workers as independent contractors rather than employees, appears to have passed.  This ballot measure is in response to California Law AB5, which @RockefellerInst fellow @LizFarmerTweets wrote about in this piece: https://t.co/tBIvpL12Lp

texts.author: RogueMisanthrope
texts.text:
â€œEmployeesâ€™ lunches are their personal property and the company is not responsible for lost or stolen personal items.â€Nobody likes a lunch thief, and I had one of the most aggressive at my office. 

There were rumors for a few months leading up to the inciting incident of someone going around and taking peoplesâ€™ lunches. Just about every day someone different would complain that their lunch was missing. 

It even happened to me once or twice, but I figured hey, itâ€™s a big office, a few people are probably just careless and grab the wrong lunch and are too embarrassed to bring it back or someone else packs their lunch and they donâ€™t know whatâ€™s in there so itâ€™s not obvious they have the wrong one, or whatever. 

Most people just brought brown bags with their names on it anyways, or identical Rubbermaid Tupperware with a little piece of labeled tape on the side. It was easy enough to mix it up. 

I had accidentally grabbed a wrong lunch once or twice, but Iâ€™d noticed before I got it open. I thought I was just more careful, or even just not as busy, as some other people in the building. 

However, other people werenâ€™t as forgiving, and a quorum made complaints to HR. They were blown off. Personally, at the time, I thought it was all much ado about nothing. 

But then it began. My wife enrolled in a French cooking class online and just about every day I was bringing fancy gourmand leftovers in for lunch. Youâ€™d think I was picking up a to go bag from a Michelin starred bistro on the way in each morning, she really threw herself into the coursework.

There were no problems for about two weeks, maybe three, until one day my lunch went missing. Considering what delicacies I had to look forward to I was pretty miffed, but I did a once over around the break room and didnâ€™t see anyone eating my lunch so figured someone grabbed my bag by accident earlier, saw how good things looked andâ€”realizing it was their lucky dayâ€”didnâ€™t bring it back to the fridge. 

I wrote the mysterious stranger off as an asshole but accepted the loss and looked forward to dinner that night instead. 

Next day I write my name on my lunch in extra bold lettering, jam the bag into the back of the fridge, and feel peace of mind. I get there come break time, nope, itâ€™s gone. 

I was pretty upset, but I figured it was a stroke of bad luck, and left it at that. What else could I do?

However, third day, out of an abundance of caution, I kept my lunch at my desk. A pain, because I had to eat it fairly early in the day to avoid spoilage, but at least Iâ€™d know where it was. 

I got up to take care of some business down the hall and when I came backâ€¦ yep, my lunch was gone.

Unfortunately that didnâ€™t help me narrow it down much at all because my desk is centrally located so everyoneâ€™s constantly passing by. 

At that point there was no possibility of the theft being arbitrary, so I approached HR and filed a complaint. Their response, practically verbatim, was, â€œEmployeesâ€™ lunches are their personal property and the company is not responsible for lost or stolen personal items.â€

The following day my wife packed a cream based soup that really had to be refrigerated. I was passing by the break room to check on my lunch practically every five minutes. Somehow it still managed to disappear. 

I was irate at this point and returned to HR and really blew my top. The best they could do was send a memo around about remembering to check the name on your lunch when you remove it from the fridge, but they made very clear that it was a routine memo and in no way related to my complaints, which were not their jurisdiction, so not an admission of responsibility, because my lunch was my own personal problem. 

The only suitable alternative to packing a lunch available in the building are these wretched shrink wrapped ham and cheese sandwiches from a vending machine. 

Theyâ€™ve been marinating in the heat for God knows how long and the bread is as stale as cork board and the meat is rancid and thereâ€™s gluey mayo smushed into the center. Itâ€™s a relic of the old office tenantsâ€™ Iâ€™m pretty sure. 

I vented daily to my wife but her only idea was to start bringing a regular sandwich and apple again to dissuade the thief and get him to move on to other lunches. 

So, determined prevent this low life scum from downgrading the quality of my lunch, I hatched an elaborate planâ€¦ Then the pandemic hit and I forgot all about this whole saga. 

I worked remotely for months and months. Then we returned, and after all that had happened globally, this was the last thing on my mind. 

But I got to the break room the first day back, frustrated from having to wear a button up and tie after months of working in pajamas, sore from my desk chair, and exhausted from small talk, only to findâ€¦ my lunch was gone. 

This was a particularly sore point because my wife and I divorced between my last lunch and work and the present one. So I did not appreciate being reminded of any past threads involving her. 

I pretty much flew into a blind rage at that point. Especially seeing that stupid worthless memo about checking the lunch bag names posted in the break room, feeling so helpless and so hungry and so alone as it was me and my lunch against the world. 

I stormed out and was determined to return the next day with a plan. 

So, I came in the following dayâ€¦ with an empty lunch bag. 

And I checked closely to be sure no one was watching andâ€¦ I switched the contents of the HR personâ€™s lunch bag into my bag. So now their lunch appeared to be my lunch. 

Theyâ€™d packed a regular brown bag, so I just discarded that, and I left, and I waited. I knew this was a pretty big gamble because it was contingent on the theory that the thief was avoiding me while having lunch, but not wary of anyone else. So would eat out in the open if there were no risk of bumping into me. 

So I made a big show of going around the office announcing that I was headed out for a meeting and I wouldnâ€™t be back until at least 3:00pm.

I even went to the trouble of moving my car out of the lot to a space two streets over. Where I then sat in my car and worked remotely for several hours before sneaking
into the building up the back stairway.

I then sat in the stairwell just outside the break room, where you can hear chatter canâ€™t be seen, and after about 20-30 minutes of waiting, I heard it. 

The sweetest sound Iâ€™ll ever hear in the office. 

(HR) â€œWhat the heck Kyle, thatâ€™s my lunch.â€ 


(Lunch thief!!) â€œNah, itâ€™s not your name on the bag.â€

(HR) Give me that! 

*Iâ€™m assuming grabs bag and sees my name.*

(HR) Yah, letâ€™s head to my office for a chat. 

The HR rep later called me in as well and said they were â€œaware of my break room hijinks,â€ but it was obvious that the point still came across loud and clear. 

They warned me that it was a violation of policy to move another employeeâ€™s lunchâ€”it took every ounce of self control for me to keep from retorting â€œI thought our lunches were our personal property and the company was not responsible for them being lost or stolen?â€ 

They informed me theyâ€™d located the thief and things would be handled accordingly. 

But better than whatever write up they might be able to issue Kyle, his reveal as the lunch thief occurred in front of the whole break room. So word quickly spread as to who had been stealing everyoneâ€™s lunches earlier last year and he is now the office pariah. 

He was in line for a promotion. The promotion is indefinitely off the table. 

And I also earned brownie points for exposing him, though more than Iâ€™m satisfied with are being attributed to HR. 

At the end of the day though, I didnâ€™t do this for this credit, or even the sweet sweet *sweet* revenge. I did it to get my lunches back.

Managementâ€™s empathetic response to employees trying to unionize.Note: I donâ€™t work here, but I used to be employed by the company. I left years ago, amicably after finding a new job. 

I saw this online from a store that is not the one I worked at and I gotta say, itâ€™s fucking embarrassing. The context here, from what I gather, is that the employees are trying to unionize. 

Management there is filled with pull-yourself-up-by-the-bootstraps type folks that think the admittedly good ESOP (that used to be way better) is worth living a life of poverty wages for. Winco gets a lot of good press for being an employee owned company but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s fairâ€”itâ€™s exactly as garbage as any retail experience and pays about as much. And I canâ€™t even describe how shocked I was when I left and was treated like an adult for the first time in the workplace. 

WinCo hides behind its employee owned status, but make no mistake the employees have zero say in anything. There are committees that are constantly overruled by corporate whenever they try to advocate for themselves. And as you can see here, management isnâ€™t above intimidation and bullying. 

Good luck to the folks still working there and I hope they find peace in the hell world we live in.

texts.author: Jaded_Praline_2137
texts.text:
In response to recent posts about pushy Costco employees.Please do not be mad at the employees. I'm speaking as one myself. We do not enjoy constantly bothering members for exec upgrades/auto renewal sign up/app downloads. Corporate demands these things.
 
In my location, numerous employees have voiced concerns about members feeling harassed because of how often we have to do this. Nothing has changed.

If you want something to change you have to voice your concerns to management/corporate.  They WILL listen to members. Is Sam's Club or BJs doing something better than Costco? Tell them! If Costco sees members turning to competitors they will act to keep your business.

EDIT: I see a few comments about employees being rude, lying, and "accidentally" signing someone up for exec when they didn't want it.  I am not trying to make an excuse for this behavior. This shouldn't be happening.

I just ask members to understand that when we ask you the same things every other week, it's not because we want to, we're told to.  If it's driving you away from Costco please speak up. Things won't change overnight, but if enough members voice opinions about the same thing, corporate will notice.

Resort information technology worker Yuscil Taveras had initially denied to special counsel Jack Smithâ€™s team that there had been any conversations at Mar-a-Lago about security footage that prosecutors subpoenaed in 2022 as part of the investigation. But once he was assigned a new public defender in July, Taveras immediately recanted his testimony and gave a statement implicating Trump and his two co-defendants in efforts to delete the footag

texts.author: Mrlejosh
texts.text:
I emailed a Valve employee about CS:GO (and got a response!)**Heres my initial email:**
> Dear John McDonald,

>I recently watched your talk at GDC 2018 about deep learning in CS:GO (which was great by the way) and I have a few questions of my own.

>A recent update came out to CS:GO which changed a variable in the game files which broke nearly all aim and vision assistance cheats, which i'm sure you are aware of. **My question is: is it possible to change other variables during updates to repeat that effect?** Using this, or a similar, method would certainly deter cheaters and potentially work as an anti cheat. That said i'm not sure how that would effect server and client interaction, as there is probably a reason this hasn't been done already.

>One of the questions at the conference talked about checking if a person really made the mouse movement and if they really are in total control of their player. **I was curious about, if using a learning program, you could track the speed of a players crosshair before taking a shot?** and using that, judge their accuracy and how straight of a line a player makes when flicking. Using a method like this could help detect aimbots because it is nearly impossible to make a completely straight line without external assistance, and doing that in milliseconds would be even harder. **If this is possible would it also be possible to use a modified version of it to detect wallhacks (seeing how close a players crosshair is to an enemy through a wall)?**

>**Why is the report function unavailable in demos and watching live matches?** Being able to report players while having all the benefits of GOTV (xray and pov) would potentially increase the accuracy of player reports. Although I do see how it could be abused by cheaters using report bots. **Tied to this question, do reports through Steam do anything relevant to CS:GO?** (pressing report in a live game/ demo brings you to the players Steam profile.) 

>**What is your/Valve's opinion on partnering with 3rd party matchmaking services like FACEIT and ESEA?** Doing so could benefit both parties by having 128 tick matchmaking servers, as well as another anticheat, which could lead to older players who stopped playing because of those problems to come back, and new players coming to CS:GO because of those features.

>**How much do you/the CS:GO dev team read feedback?** As replies from you guys in the subreddit are sparse.

>All of my questions are in bold, the surrounding text is context and further explanation for the questions. Please pardon my bad explaining skills as well.

>Your talk really inspired me to do more Overwatch cases and be overall a more active member of the community so thanks for that.

>-MrLeJosh

**His response:**
>Changing variables is feasible, but itâ€™s just a little treadmill. It breaks cheats for a small amount of time to work around but requires a fair amount of work on our side. Thatâ€™s typically a bad tradeoff to make.

>The learner we use tracks velocity of the view angles alreadyâ€”thatâ€™s one of the main things it is looking at. Itâ€™s not intuitively clear what a wall hack looks for.

>I donâ€™t have a well-formed opinion on third party matchmaking services. At first blush, it seems like they provide value to our mutual customers, which is great.

>We read the feedback sent to the feedback alias, although there are times where the volume is too large for us to read every piece of mail sent.

 
>Cheers,


>McJohn

(I shrunk down spaces between paragraphs so this post isn't *too* long)

Obviously John didn't answer all my questions fully, which I assume was due to Valve not wanting to release info on certain topics.

I am sharing this in case anyone else had these questions, and to enlighten those who have been skeptical on Valves presence in CS:GO. (including me)

If you want to watch the GDC conference it is available [here](https://youtu.be/ObhK8lUfIlc)

I asked John McDonald for permission to post this. (He said yes in case you weren't sure.)


EDIT: I had a great time in this thread, I read nearly everyone's comments and replied to as many as I could. John even replied to a comment! I hope this thread helped out some people who were hazy/weary about the state of anticheat in CS:GO.

texts.author: abc7ny
texts.text: At least 18 New York City employees were arrested on Thursday for allegedly stealing identities to get financial benefits during the COVID pandemic. The suspects are accused of impersonating homeless people at the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, and using their names to illegally get their pandemic benefits. Some of those homeless people died during the pandemic. The suspects include five Department of Homeless services workers, as well as employees of the NYPD, MTA, USPS and NYCHA. Prosecutors believe they are responsible for obtaining nearly $1.2 million in fraudulent benefits between April 2020 and October 2021. Officials say approximately 170 people had their identities stolen. It is alleged that the five DHS employees got shelter resident information from paper and digital files and shared them with the group. "Stealing the identities of New Yorkers, many of them homeless, and defrauding a critical social safety program during one of the most challenging times in our city's history is downright shameful and we allege criminal," said District Attorney Alvin Bragg. Prosecutors say they were looking into a DHS employee who may have been manufacturing ghost guns when investigators discovered the other alleged fraud. All of the defendants pleaded not guilty on Thursday and the judge set bail for almost every suspect.#nyc #fraud #news
